column4: Hey all, I have a problem with 12.04 LTS. I've resized the partition twice (shrinking it down leaving a few GBs free each time) with a GParted boot-stick. the first time all went well, but now it boot. The only difference is I moved the swap to a different primary partition. It won't boot in rescue mood or anything. It just freezes at the loading screen (UBUNTU with the dots underneath). I have 3g of RAM
but now it won't boot*
Looks like maybe you've changed the partition number of the  root  filesystem.
Grub tries but will not boot?  What error do you get?
Ubuntu is the first partition, and always has been. GRUB loads, and I can get to it checking battery state (I'm on a laptop) but it catches there. No error.
So you have only one Linux partition?
I think it's a different problem.
I have three. 1: Ubuntu ext4; 2: ext2 (formerly swap), 3: ufs, 4: swap (new)
http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=1794383
Did you change fstab entries?
What is ufs?
No, I didn't. ufs is the native fs for FreeBSD (which I'm chatting from now)
So you moved the swap partition from the second to the forth partition?
Yes, as I was needing a unified space to act as intermediary betweeun Ubuntu and FreeBSD
And Ubuntu is in the first partition and always has been?  /dev/sda1
Yes
Why couldn't it stay there as the third partition?
Because gparted doesn't handle ufs, though it recognizes it. Otherwise I would have made ext2 third and ufs fourth
You created the new ext2 partition (/dev/sda2) for what reason?
Well, you could have just changed the partition's ID
To transfer a massive amount of files from ubuntu to FreeBSD and to act as the home of Dropbox on Ubuntu (no FreeBSD support)
You can change partition IDs non-destructively with fdisk
Thanks, I'll see what I can do. Thanks for the help.
Ok, well at any rate, see: http://askubuntu.com/questions/205695/12-04-hangs-at-checking-battery-state
